tit.e: Godaimon (The five major family crests in Japan)
Godaimon (The five major family crests in Japan)
Godaimon (The five major family crests in Japan)

sen.j: 五大紋（ごだいもん）は、日本の家紋のうち、一般的に特に多く分布する藤、桐、鷹の羽、木瓜、片喰の5つの紋のことを指す。
sen.e: Godaion means the five family crests which are especially widely distributed throughout Japan, they are Fuji (wisteria), Kiri (paulownia), Takanoha (feathers of hawks), Mokko (a cut end surface of gourd), and Katabami (yellow sorrel).

Godaion refers to the five family crest designs that are especially widely used throughout Japan, and they are fuji (wisteria), kiri (paulownia), takanoha (feathers of hawks), mokko (cross-section of a gourd), and katabami (yellow sorrel).
sen.cmt: "means" replaced with "refers to," "family crests" changed to "family crest designs," "a cut end surface of gourd" changed to "cross-section of a gourd"
sen.e: Godaion refers to the five family crest designs that are especially widely used throughout Japan, and they are fuji (wisteria), kiri (paulownia), takanoha (feathers of hawks), mokko (cross-section of a gourd), and katabami (yellow sorrel).

sen.j: これらを、いつごろに誰が何を基準にして定めたものかは不詳である。
sen.e: It is unknown when and who designated these patterns as five major crests and what criteria the designation is based on.
It is unknown when and who designated these designs as the five major crests, and on what criteria the designation was based.
sen.cmt: "the" added before "five major crests," "on" from the end of the sentence brought before "what"
sen.e: It is unknown when and who designated these designs as the five major crests, and on what criteria the designation was based.

sen.j: またこれらに、蔦、茗荷、沢瀉、橘、柏の5つを加えて「十大紋」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In addition to these five crests, five more crests- Tsuta (ivy), Myoga (a kind of ginger), Omodaka (arrowhead), Tachibana (citrus) and Kashiwa (oak) are added to be called Judaimon (the ten major family crests in Japan).

In addition to these, five more crest designs, tsuta (ivy), myoga (a type of ginger), omodaka (arrowhead), tachibana (mandarin orange tree) and kashiwa (oak), make up Judaimon (the ten major family crests in Japan).
sen.cmt: first "five crests" deleted, "five more crests" changed to "five more crest designs," "citrus" changed to "mandarin orange tree," "are added to be called" replaced with "make up"
sen.e: In addition to these, five more crest designs, tsuta (ivy), myoga (a type of ginger), omodaka (arrowhead), tachibana (mandarin orange tree) and kashiwa (oak), make up Judaimon (the ten major family crests in Japan).

sen.j: 日本家紋研究所のデータでは、全国平均で最も多い占有率を示したものは「片喰紋」（約9パーセント）で、五大紋の内で最少の占有率は「桐紋」（約5パーセント）であったという。
sen.e: According to a data presented by Japan Family Crest Research Institute, the family crest which had the largest share of the national average was 'Katabami-mon' (about 9%), and 'Kiri-mon' had the smallest share of the 5 major family crests (about 5%).
sen.cmt: 日本家紋研究所→定訳不明
sen.e: According to data presented by Japan Family Crest Research Institute, the most commonly used family crest, on national average, is "katabami-mon" (about 9%), and the least commonly used crest is "kiri-mon" (about 5%) among the five major family crests.
sen.cmt: "a data" changed to "the data," sentence reworded
sen.e: According to data presented by Japan Family Crest Research Institute, the most commonly used family crest, on national average, is "katabami-mon" (about 9%), and the least commonly used crest is "kiri-mon" (about 5%) among the five major family crests.

sen.j: ちなみに、この日本家紋研究所調べの全国平均占有率の並びでは、上位から片喰・木瓜・鷹の羽・柏・藤、次に桐・蔦・梅・橘・目結の順である。
sen.e: Incidentally, in the ranking of the share of family crests based on the national average conducted by Japan Family Crest Research Institute, Katabami ranked the top, followed by Mokko, Takanoha, Kashiwa, Fuji, Kiri, Tsuta, Ume (Japanese plum), Tachibana, and Merui.

Incidentally, based on the national average from the survey conducted by Japan Family Crest Research Institute, family crest designs can be listed from the most commonly used to the least commonly used as: katabami, mokko, takanoha, kashiwa, fuji, kiri, tsuta, ume (Japanese plum), tachibana, then meyui (kanoko (dappled pattern)).
sen.cmt: sentence reworded, "Merui" changed to "meyui," explanation for "meyui" added
sen.e: Incidentally, based on the national average from the survey conducted by Japan Family Crest Research Institute, family crest designs can be listed from the most commonly used to the least commonly used as: katabami, mokko, takanoha, kashiwa, fuji, kiri, tsuta, ume (Japanese plum), tachibana, then meyui (kanoko (dappled pattern)).

sen.j: サイト「日本の苗字七千傑」の「都道府県別代表家紋一覧」には、特に多く使用されている家紋を、都道府県別に10個程度選出して表にまとめられている。
sen.e: A website named '7,000 Japanese family names' provides 'a list of reprentative family crests by prefecture' in which about 10 most widely used family crests in each prefecture are chosen and shown in a table.
sen.cmt: 日本の苗字七千傑→定訳不明
sen.e: A website named "Seven thousand Japanese family names" provides "a list of representative family crests by prefecture," in which about ten most widely used family crests in each prefecture are chosen and shown in a table.
sen.cmt: "7,000" changed to "Seven thousand," comma added after "prefectures," "10" changed to "ten"
sen.e: A website named "Seven thousand Japanese family names" provides "a list of representative family crests by prefecture," in which about ten most widely used family crests in each prefecture are chosen and shown in a table.

sen.j: それによると、藤、桐、鷹の羽、木瓜、片喰の紋がそれぞれ、46の都道府県の約半分、またはそれ以上において「代表家紋」としてランクインしている。
sen.e: According to the list, Fuji, Kiri, Takanoha, Mokko, and Katabami are respectively ranked in the category of representative family crests in more than half of the 46 prefectures.
According to the list, fuji, kiri, takanoha, mokko, and katabami are all ranked as "representative family crests" in more than half of the 46 prefectures.
According to the list, fuji, kiri, takanoha, mokko, and katabami are all ranked as "representative family crests" in more than half of the 46 prefectures.

sen.j: この5つの家紋が特に普及している主な理由は以下の通り。
sen.e: The reasons that these five family crests are especially widely used are as follows.
The reasons why these five family crests are especially widely used are listed below.
sen.cmt: "that" replaced with "why," "as follows" changed to "listed below"
sen.e: The reasons why these five family crests are especially widely used are listed below.

sen.j: フジ (植物)
sen.e: Fuji (Wisteria (plant))
Fuji (Wisteria (plant))
Fuji (Wisteria (plant))

sen.j: 藤紋は、藤の花や葉を図案化したものである。
sen.e: Fuji-mon is a pattern of wisteria flowers and leaves.
Fuji-mon is a pattern of wisteria flowers and leaves.
Fuji-mon is a pattern of wisteria flowers and leaves.

sen.j: 一般家庭での普及はあるものの、藤原氏流（97家）の使用例は、うち7家のみであるといわれている。
sen.e: Whereas Fuji-mon are widely used in general households, only 7 (of 97) families of the Fujiwara clan lineage are said to use Fuji-mon.
While fuji-mon design is widely used in general households, it is said that only seven (out of 97) families of the Fujiwara clan lineage use them.
sen.cmt: "Whereas" replaced with "While," "designs" added after "fuji-mon," "7" changed to "seven," sentence reworded
sen.e: While fuji-mon design is widely used in general households, it is said that only seven (out of 97) families of the Fujiwara clan lineage use them.

sen.j: 藤原氏系の流れで、名前に「藤」を入れた苗字（佐藤姓、加藤姓、斉藤姓など）を用いる家があり、その多くが藤紋を使っている。
sen.e: Many families of the Fujiwara clan lineage whose family names include the letter '藤' (such as Sato, Kato, Saito), use Fuji-mon.
Many families of the Fujiwara clan lineage, whose family names include the letter '藤' (such as Sato, Kato, Saito), use the fuji-mon design.
sen.cmt: comma added after "lineage," "Fuji-mon" changed to "the fuji-mon designs"
sen.e: Many families of the Fujiwara clan lineage, whose family names include the letter '藤' (such as Sato, Kato, Saito), use the fuji-mon design.

sen.j: 佐藤姓では、藤紋より源氏車紋を用いる者が多い。
sen.e: Many Sato families use Genjiguruma-mon better than Fuji-mon.
Many families with "Sato" as their family names use genjiguruma (a cartwheel of a cattle-drawn carriage)-mon rather than fuji-mon.
Many families with "Sato" as their family names use genjiguruma (a cartwheel of a cattle-drawn carriage)-mon rather than fuji-mon.

sen.j: 桐紋
sen.e: Kiri-mon (paulownia patterns)
Kiri-mon (paulownia designs)
Kiri-mon (paulownia designs)

sen.j: 桐の花及び葉を図案化したものである。
sen.e: Kiri-mon is a pattern of paulownia flowers and leaves.
Kiri-mon is a design made of paulownia flowers and leaves.
Kiri-mon is a design made of paulownia flowers and leaves.

sen.j: 菊花紋章と共に皇室の用いた家紋である。
sen.e: Kiri-mon is the family crest which was used by the Imperial family along with the Imperial Crest of the Chrysanthemum.
Along with the Imperial Crest of the Chrysanthemum, it is the family crest which was used by the Imperial family.
Along with the Imperial Crest of the Chrysanthemum, it is the family crest which was used by the Imperial family.

sen.j: 次第に天皇から将軍家へ、将軍家から家臣へと下賜されていった。
sen.e: Later, Kiri-mon was gradually given to Shogun family from Emperor as an imperial gift, and to vassals from Shogun family.
Gradually, kiri-mon was given from the Emperor to the shogun family as an imperial gift, and then from the shogun family to the vassals.
Gradually, kiri-mon was given from the Emperor to the shogun family as an imperial gift, and then from the shogun family to the vassals.

sen.j: 名家から庶民まで幅広く流行し、現在では、比較的ポピュラーな家紋として定着している。
sen.e: It was widely used by many people from Meika (important noble familes) to families of common people, and today, it is prevalent as a relatively popular family crest.
It became widely popular among people from meika (court nobles, important or distinguished families) to commoners, and today, it is prevalent as a relatively popular family crest.
It became widely popular among people from meika (court nobles, important or distinguished families) to commoners, and today, it is prevalent as a relatively popular family crest.

sen.j: 鷹の羽
sen.e: Takanoha
Takanoha
Takanoha

sen.j: 鷹の羽を図案化したものである。
sen.e: Takanoha is a pattern of feathers of hawks.
Takanoha is a design of hawk feathers.
Takanoha is a design of hawk feathers.

sen.j: 主に、並び鷹の羽や違い鷹の羽などといったものがある。
sen.e: There are several variations of patterns in which feathers are arranged side by side, or two feathers are crossed each other.
There are several designs in which feathers are arranged side by side or two feathers cross each other.
There are several designs in which feathers are arranged side by side or two feathers cross each other.

sen.j: 江戸時代には、武士の間で流行した。
sen.e: During the Edo period, Takanoha-mon was caught on Samurai warriors.
During the Edo period, takanoha-mon was popular among samurai.
During the Edo period, takanoha-mon was popular among samurai.

sen.j: 木瓜紋
sen.e: Mokko-mon
Mokko-mon
Mokko-mon

sen.j: 木瓜紋は、瓜の切り口や瓜そのものを図案化したものとする説や鳥の巣とする説など何を図案化したのかの見解や説が幾つかある。
sen.e: There are several opinions and theories about what Mokko-mon is designed, one of which is that Mokko-mon is a design of a cut end surface of a gourd or a gourd itself, the other theory is that Mokko-mon is a design of a bird's nest.

There are several opinions and theories about what mokko-mon designs are based on, such as a theory that suggests that mokko-mon is a design of a cross-section of a gourd or the gourd itself, and an opinion that suggests that mokko-mon is a design of a bird's nest.

There are several opinions and theories about what mokko-mon designs are based on, such as a theory that suggests that mokko-mon is a design of a cross-section of a gourd or the gourd itself, and an opinion that suggests that mokko-mon is a design of a bird's nest.

sen.j: カタバミ
sen.e: Katabami-mon
Katabami-mon
Katabami-mon

sen.j: 片喰（酢漿草）紋は、カタバミを図案化したもので桐紋の次に流行した植物図案の紋である。
sen.e: Katabami (sakusho-sou)-mon is a pattern of a plant yellow sorrel, which became the second most popular crest after Kiri-mon (paulownia pattern).
Katabami (sakusho-so)-mon is a design of yellow sorrel flowers, and as a crest, whose design is based on plants, it became the second most popular crest after kiri-mon (paulownia design).
Katabami (sakusho-so)-mon is a design of yellow sorrel flowers, and as a crest, whose design is based on plants, it became the second most popular crest after kiri-mon (paulownia design).

sen.j: 子孫繁栄の願いを込めた紋として、大衆に広く使用されている。
sen.e: Ktabami-mon is widely used as a family crest by the general public in hope of being blessed with fertility and family prosperity.
Ktabami-mon is widely used by the general public as family crests, because it symbolizes their hopes for fertility and family prosperity.
Ktabami-mon is widely used by the general public as family crests, because it symbolizes their hopes for fertility and family prosperity.
